g.title: Rectangle
g.desc: Singleton Ensure a class only has one instance, and provide a...
g.text: SingletonEnsure a class only has one instance, and provide a global point of access to it.

g.title: Rectangle.47
g.desc: Clients require global access to the same instance
g.text: Clients require global access to the same instance

g.title: Folded Corner.41
g.desc: We can provide global access to the same instance by using th...

g.text: We can provide global access to the same instance by using the Singleton design pattern. This can be convenient, for example, in case of a logging instance. A logging instance is something which is required by all our clients and must be identical for all our clients. Via Singleton we can ensure that our complete system is ‘talking’ to the same logging instance and we can request the object via a single access point, instead of having it to continuously pass around in our system.

g.title: Folded Corner.20
g.desc: We can change the singleton instance by using inheritance. Th...

g.text: We can change the singleton instance by using inheritance. This provides a way to change the singleton implementation without having to change our clients. This is the advantage a singleton instance provides over a static class or namespace. The only not OCP related aspect is that we need to modify the ‘Instance’ call to return a different singleton object.

g.title: Rectangle.57
g.desc: Clients require flexibility in the globally accessible instance
g.text: Clients require flexibility in the globally accessible instance

g.title: Folded Corner.59
g.desc: Incase we would provide a static class or functionality in a ...

g.text: Incase we would provide a static class or functionality in a namespace we are bounded to that implementation. By using the Singleton pattern we provide global accessibility, but also the flexibility of change by using an object. Using objects ensures we can use inheritance and return a different concrete implementation from our Singleton without changing the clients.

g.title: Folded Corner.62
g.desc: It makes clients of a singleton harder to test, because we ca...

g.text: It makes clients of a singleton harder to test, because we cannot mock the singleton dependency. When clients are dependent on the state of the singleton we need to force the singleton in our test code to go to the correct state. This can be complex and/or time consuming.

g.title: Rectangle.67
g.desc: Clarify design intent / safety by restricting object creation
g.text: Clarify design intent / safety by restricting object creation

g.title: Folded Corner.69
g.desc: We need to restrict object creation to a single instance, bec...

g.text: We need to restrict object creation to a single instance, because instantiating multiple could cause an error or a risk in human/system safety. For example, in a medical device that controls a robotic arm. It could be that safety risks are involved when the control of that arm is accidently initialized multiple times. This could cause multiple points of control, causing the system to fail and potentially harm a human.

g.title: Rectangle.73
g.desc: Clients are independent of the Singleton state
g.text: Clients are independent of the Singleton state

g.title: Folded Corner.76
g.desc: Communication is unidirectional, from client to Singleton. Cl...

g.text: Communication is unidirectional, from client to Singleton. Clients are not dependent on the state of the Singleton, meaning without the Singleton the client can still function in the same way. This provides loose coupling and has advantage when we test a client that uses a Singleton. We don’t have to provide a mocking implementation to force our client in a certain state.

g.title: Folded Corner.80
g.desc: Clients can easily access the singleton object, because it is...

g.text: Clients can easily access the singleton object, because it is globally accessible. This could result in an architectural growth where a lot of clients are dependent on the same singleton. This result in a high level of coupling to a single instance. A change in the singleton affects the whole system and can be hard to oversee.

g.title: Folded Corner.83
g.desc: In case our class is dependent on the state of the Singleton ...

g.text: In case our class is dependent on the state of the Singleton object it can be very hard to re-use that class. This is because the Singleton somehow controls the state of the class. When we want to use that class we should also preset the singleton in a correct state. It forces developers to immerse into the implementation in case dependencies are buried inside other objects. On top of that, refactoring our code might result in re-ordering the sequence incorrectly. Meaning, our class (dependent on the singleton) is used before the singleton is set in a correct state. This could result in bugs that are hard to resolve.
